resources.string: This introduction will help you understand how to use this app and will only take a few minutes of your time. \n\nYou can navigate by swiping the pages from right to left. Let\'s begin.
At the first run of the app \"edit mode\" will be activated and you will be presented with 6 pictograms. This is called a "board". \n\nYou can start editing by tapping on a pictogram.
From the plus buttons you can add another board. The trashbin deletes the current board you are on.

Tapping on a pictogram will show you a set of options. Setting this pictogram as a tree board means adding a board inside it, such that when you click on that pictogram, a new board will be displayed. \n\nYou can also delete and set an image.
After choosing to set an image you can tap on the current empty box to select a source for the picture.
You should also set the title and optionally the text to be spoken. \n\nInstead of the text to be spoken you can register a sound by pressing the record button. Click the save icon when you\'re done.
You have a couple of options to choose your pictograms from.
Selecting to search from the database will position the cursor at the top and you can start typing. Let\'s search for the word \"bus\". \n\nPress enter when finished to start searching.

The search results will display a list of pictograms which you can scroll through until you find the one you like. Select one by tapping on it. This will cause the app to download the image and display it on the preview section. \n\nIt will also complete the title field with the title of the image you selected.

You can enter the main menu by tapping on the three dots in the top-right corner. This will present you with all the options available. \n\nThe option \"manage boards\" lets you save, load and create a new board. When saving you can use \"save as\" to give your board a name. The name will appear when you will load a new board.

The \"Lock\" option locks the screen and hides the options menu and the system bar. Doing so prevents others from accessing the menu and making changes. \n\nTo exit the lock mode position your finger at the top of the screen and swipe down and select unlock.
Change the settings of the board

The settings menu allows you to make changes to your board configuration. More pictograms can be displayed by selecting the number of rows and columns. \n\nFinally, you can disallow swipe movements from one board to the other and instead use the navigational arrows. This is available if you have more than one board.
This project is free and open source and was done in collaboration with University of Eastern Piedmont. \n\nPlease consider supporting our efforts and donating.
